Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev

(2) Summary

The Web is an amazingly robust and constantly evolving body of shared concepts. Most developers today use APIs as a standard way of how capabilities are encapsulated and exposed. For some popular APIs, SDKs may allow developers to conveniently ignore API details. For API designers and users of less popular APIs, however, understanding how Web APIs work helps a lot to become a better designer and user of them. Web Concepts [http://webconcepts.info/] captures many standards that can help to design better APIs, and to easier understand well-designed APIs. In this presentation, Erik briefly explains the idea behind Web Concepts. He also demos how the site can be forked and customized to cover and document a "personalized Web API surface" that helps developers and organizations to better understand which Web surface they are surfing, and which of their APIs expose certain Web concepts.

(11) Web Concepts: Specifications [http://webconcepts.info/specs/]

  • Specifications define values for existing concepts [Web Concepts: Concepts and Values [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/] (1)]
  • RFC 7234 (HTTP/1.1 Caching) [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/RFC/7234] defines new values for three existing Web Concepts:
    • HTTP Cache Directives [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/]: max-age [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/max-age], max-stale [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/max-stale], min-fresh [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/min-fresh], must-revalidate [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/must-revalidate], no-cache [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/no-cache], no-store [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/no-store], no-transform [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/no-transform], only-if-cached [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/only-if-cached], private [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/private], proxy-revalidate [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/proxy-revalidate], public [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/public], s-maxage [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-cache-directive/s-maxage]
    • HTTP Header Fields [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/]: Age [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Age], Cache-Control [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Cache-Control], Expires [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Expires], Pragma [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Pragma], Warning [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Warning]
    • HTTP Warn Codes [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-warn-code/]: 110 [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-warn-code/110], 111 [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-warn-code/111], 112 [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-warn-code/112], 113 [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-warn-code/113], 199 [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-warn-code/199], 214 [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-warn-code/214], 299 [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-warn-code/299]
  • Specifications add one or more values for one or more concepts
  • Specification series [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/] define naming patterns for automated processing


Web Concepts: The Basics Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev

(12) Web Concepts: Concepts and Values [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/]

  • Concepts establish a namespace for sharing values with shared meanings
  • HTTP Header Fields [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/] are one concept with currently 192 distinct values
    • The currently listed values all are defined in W3C/IETF specifications
    • If required the list could be extended with de-facto standards as well
  • Link Relations [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/link-relation/] are an extensible and fuzzy concept
    • 103 link relations have been established as registered values
    • Hypermedia applications often will use private URI-identified relations
    • It is possible that only registered link relations are good candidates for sharing


Web Concepts: The Basics Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev

(14) Specification Series 

    <primary id="IETF" href="http://www.ietf.org/">
        <name short="IETF">Internet Engineering Task Force</name>
        <secondary id="RFC">
            <name short="RFC">Request for Comments</name>
            <id-pattern>^(\d+)$</id-pattern>
            <md-pattern>$1</md-pattern>
            <name-pattern>RFC $1</name-pattern>
            <uri-pattern>urn:ietf:rfc:$1</uri-pattern>
            <url-pattern>http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc$1</url-pattern>
        </secondary>
        <secondary id="I-D">
            <name short="I-D">Internet Draft</name>
            <id-pattern>^(.+)$</id-pattern>
            <md-pattern>$1</md-pattern>
            <name-pattern>Internet Draft $1</name-pattern>
            <uri-pattern>urn:ietf:id:$1</uri-pattern>
            <url-pattern>http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-$1</url-pattern>
        </secondary>
    </primary>
  • specs.xml (line 4-22)


Web Concepts: The Basics Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev

(15) Concept Configuration 

    <concept id="http-header">
        <title-singular>HTTP Header Field</title-singular>
        <title-plural>HTTP Header Fields</title-plural>
        <iana-registry>http://www.iana.org/assignments/message-headers/message-headers.xhtml</iana-registry>
    </concept>
  • concepts.xml (line 20-24)
    <concept id="http-warn-code">
        <title-singular>HTTP Warn Code</title-singular>
        <title-plural>HTTP Warn Codes</title-plural>
        <iana-registry>https://www.iana.org/assignments/http-warn-codes/http-warn-codes.xhtml</iana-registry>
    </concept>
    <concept id="http-cache-directive">
        <title-singular>HTTP Cache Directive</title-singular>
        <title-plural>HTTP Cache Directives</title-plural>
        <iana-registry>http://www.iana.org/assignments/http-cache-directives/http-cache-directives.xhtml</iana-registry>
    </concept>

Web Concepts: The Future Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev

(17) Constraining Concepts

  • Ignore/remove specifications that you are not interested in
  • Ignore/remove specification series that you are not interested in
  • Ignore/remove organizations that you are not interested in
  • The resulting specifications are your Web Concepts
  • They can be the starting point for API guidelines [http://apistylebook.com/]


Web Concepts: The Future Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev

(18) Custom Concepts

  • Add specifications that you are interested in
  • Add specification series that you are interested in
  • Add organizations that you are interested in
  • Anything that has potential for reuse can and should be added
  • The resulting specifications are your Web Concepts
  • They can be the starting point for API guidelines [http://apistylebook.com/]


Web Concepts: The Future Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev

(19) Concept Coverage

  • Track concept value usage across APIs
  • Create a dashboard of concept/value popularity (possibly over time)
  • Can be done through code analysis (up to a certain point)
  • Probably works better/easier through service fabric instrumentation
  • Ideally separate tooling and backed by an API/format for representing usage data
  • Could even detect difference between declared/used Web Concepts


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev

(21) APIs are Languages

  • APIs are languages designed around existing building blocks
  • Web Concepts captures building blocks for design and documentation
  • Web Concepts can be tailored to only represent supported building blocks
  • Web Concepts can be extended to also represent custom building blocks
  • Web Concepts could be extended to also reflect building block usage


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web: The Path of the Dev
